required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Headache and Childbirth in a Chronic Pain Population
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Headache and Childbirth in a Chronic Pain Population

brief_summary.textblock: Headache and backache are common symptoms following childbirth. The incidence of these symptoms have been shown to increase during the postpartum period between 5 to 12 months following delivery. By 12 months postpartum up to 45% and 65% of women experience headache and backache, respectively. While studies have reported headache and backache as frequently persistent symptoms beyond the first year postpartum, few studies have specifically interrogated women seeking specialist pain physician input or identified predisposing risk factors. Finally there is little known about typically described pain characteristics of women who suffer with chronic postpartum headache and backache. We aim to compare the prevalence of chronic headache in women that have versus have not experienced childbirth.

primary_outcome.description: Percentage of patients with chronic headache in women who have given birth and who have not given birth

secondary_outcome.description: 1 to 10 scale. 1 is almost no pain, 10 is worst pain imaginable
How many days per month did patients have worst headaches
Percentage of headache in the postpartum period in women who have given birth
Association between demographics/headache characteristics/predisposing risk factors and postpartum headache

secondary_outcome.measure: Risk factors for developing acute or acutely worsened headache within 5 days of delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Association between demographic, obstetric or anesthesia related factors and acute or acutely worsened headache within 5 days of delivery

arm_group.description: Women attending chronic pain clinic who have previously experienced childbirth
Women attending chronic pain clinic who have not previously experienced childbirth

study_pop.textblock: Women who went to the pain clinic and fulfill the inclusion and exclusion criteria.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Women greater than 18 years old
- Agreeing to be contacted for research purposes.
- Able to read and understand English who have had agreed to be contacted with a valid email address
Exclusion Criteria:
- Self identified as non-female
- Age <18 years old.
- Women without computer or electronic device access or valid email address and women who did not respond
